00043 /**
00044  @mainpage Physgame
00045  The Physgame engine is an abstraction layer between less portable, less user friendly, more sophistciated
00046  libraries and the game you want to make. If we do our jobs right this will save time and effort making and porting
00047  games between a variety of platforms. If you link only against this library, not a single line of your
00048  Standard compliant C++ code should need to change between platforms. At this early stage we are proving the
00049  concept with "Catch!" our first sample game. It Currently runs on Linux, Windows and Mac OS X with an Identical
00050  codebase, when we are done with "Catch!" We want it to have one codebase, and downloadable in the Iphone
00051  app store, on the PS3, Wii downloadon Steam, and in a variety of linux repositories.
00052 
00053  To get the latest news on development checkout: http://gitorious.org/physgame
00054  Or check the webpage http://www.blacktoppstudios.com
00055 
00056  @section Engine Structure
00057   @subpage mainloop1 "Main Loop Flow"
00058 
00059   @ref phys::World "World - It integrates everything"
00060 
00061   @ref phys::EventManager "Events - Handling messages, event and interupts from the outisde"
00062 
00063   @subpage actorcontainer1 "Actor Container - Keeping track of our in game objects"
00064 
00065  @section Types Data Types
00066   @ref phys::Vector3
00067 
00068   @ref phys::Vector3WActor
00069

00071

00077

00079

00081   @ref phys::ActorBase "Actors - Items in the world"
00082 
00083   @ref phys::EventBase
00084 
00085   @ref phys::GraphicsManager
00086 
00087  @section Optional Optional Engine Components
00088   @ref phys::WorldQueryTool
00089 */

00138     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00139     /// @class World
00140     /// @headerfile world.h
00141     /// @brief This is the main entry point for the entire library.
00142     /// @details The physworld coordinates and integrates all the underlying subsystems,
00143     /// Currently Ogre3d is used for 3d Graphics, Bullet is used for physics, and
00144     /// SDL is used for user input and window management. Games will need a
00145     /// container for all the playing pieces. It makes sense to tie all of this
00146     /// functionality into one world object.
00147     ///////////////////////////////////////
00148     class World
00149     {
00150         private:
00151             friend class PhysicsManager;
00152 
00153             //SDL Objects
00154             SDL_Surface *SDLscreen;
00155             bool HasSDLBeenInitialized;
00156 
00157             //Try to retrieve ogre settinss
00158             void LoadOgreSettings();
00159 
00160             //Manages the windows all the graphics will be drawn to
00161             void CreateRenderWindow();
00162             void DestroyRenderWindow();
00163 
00164             //Used by the constructors
00165             /// @internal
00166             /// @brief This is called by all the constructors so that the is one unified place to have all the settings made.
00167             /// @param GeographyLowerBounds This is the lower boundary of the phyiscs estimation.
00168             /// @param GeographyUpperbounds This is the upper boundary of the phyiscs estimation.
00169             /// @param MaxPhysicsProxies This is an estimation of the limit of bodies in the physics world.
00170             /// @param LogFileName This is the place that log messages get sent to.
00171             /// @param ManagerToBeAdded This is a vector of manager pointers that will be used instead of creating the default ones
00172             void Construct( const Vector3 &GeographyLowerBounds,
00173                             const Vector3 &GeographyUpperbounds,
00174                             const unsigned short int &MaxPhysicsProxies,
00175                             std::string LogFileName,
00176                             std::vector < ManagerBase* > ManagerToBeAdded);
00177 
00178             void SanityChecks();
00179             void TestLogger();
00180             template <class T> void OneLogTest(T Data, string DataType,string Message1 = "Logging and Throwing a ", string Message2 = "Logging a ");
00181 
00182             //Settings for Engine Functionality
00183             string WindowName;
00184             Whole TargetFrameLength;
00185             Whole FrameTime;
00186 
00187             /// @internal
00188             /// @brief This is a listing of the priority and the Manager, and a pointer to the manager.
00189             std::list< ManagerBase* > ManagerList;

00191         public:
00192             //Ogre objects
00193             /// @internal
00194             /// @brief This is the core of the Ogre rendering system.
00195             /// @details Even thought the largest part of ogre is 3d rendering, it does not belong in the graphics manager. It is also responsible for a
00196             /// large number other services, such as logging, multithreading, and timing.
00197             Ogre::Root* OgreRoot;

00228             /// @details This constructor allows for an easier way to define the boundaries for items moving about inside the physworld.
00229             /// @param GeographyLowerBounds_ The lower limiasked Jan 29 '09 at 9:27ts for the size of the physics simulation
00230             /// @param GeographyUpperbounds_ The Upper limits for the size of the physics simulation
00231             /// @param MaxPhysicsProxies_ This is the amount of Actors (Also called Proxies) allowed in a physics simulation.

00239             /// @brief Descriptive constructor
00240             /// @details This constructor allows for an easier way to define the boundaries for items moving about inside the physworld.
00241             /// This constructor provides no default arguments, but allows for maximum customization. In addition to everything the other
00242             /// constructors this one can accept a vector of pointers to managers. They will be add
00243             /// @param GeographyLowerBounds_ The lower limits for the size of the physics simulation
00244             /// @param GeographyUpperbounds_ The Upper limits for the size of the physics simulation

00246             /// @param LogFileName This is the place that log messages get sent to.
00247             /// @param ManagerToBeAdded This is a vector of manager pointers that will be used instead of creating new ones

00249                     const Vector3 &GeographyUpperbounds_,

00251                     const std::string &LogFileName,
00252                     const std::vector <ManagerBase*> &ManagerToBeAdded);

00254             /// @brief Default constructor
00255             /// @details This simply performs the same work as the descriptive constructor with some sane, but small, limits. It will give you a world which expands for 100 units from the Origin, and only allows 10 Adows.
00256             World();
00257 
00258             /// @brief Deconstructor
00259             /// @details This Tears down all the items create by the physworld, and safely frees any graphical resources, we will also delete any Objects passed into the
00260             /// Physworld by pointer. We will not delete any pointers we pass out (like from the Events from the Event manager)
00261             ~World();

00263         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00264         // Logging
00265         ///////////////////////////////////////
00266             /// @brief Runtime Event logging Function
00267             /// @details Be careful with this function, even though it appears to be a template, it does not support every data type. If Physgame is
00268             /// Compiled as a Shared Object, Dynamic Linked Library, or some other kind of stand alone library It will only support data types
00269             /// that are called internally, Currently that list includes: string, char, short int, int, long int, unsigned short int, unsigned int
00270             /// unsigned long int, bool, float, double, long double, wchar_t, size_t, Real, Whole, String, Vector3, RawEvent and MetaCode.
00271             /// If compiled statically it should support any data type which supports output streams.
00272             /// @param Message This is what will be streamed to the log
00273             template <class T> void Log(T Message);
00274 
00275             /// @brief This is the preferred way to throw an exception currently
00276             /// @details This will log the Message, and will throw an exception with the Message included. Currently this supports all the Data
00277             /// type the Log function supports
00278             /// @param Message This will be streamed to the log, then used in a thrown exception.
00279             template <class T> void LogAndThrow(T Message);

00294         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00295         // Timing system methods
00296         ///////////////////////////////////////
00297             /// @brief Retrieves the amount of milliseconds we would like each iteration of the Main Loop to be
00298             /// @details In practice harI've done some more testing, started out digging through the code to see if there was anything wrong, there seemed to be random extra words inside our code that the compiler didn't mind that shouldn't be there.  like there was a " Schedule : " right after a line where a pointer was initialized.  I only found such occurrences in gamebase.cpp though, removed them and did two tests.  First test I was just randomly clicking and then I inadvertently threw the metal sphere down into the abyss, the sphere was really close to the camera when this happened, about to go over.  Second time I ran the game trying to click stuff, I simply couldn't click anything.  I even tried zooming in on the robots, although I can only get so close to them before I have to tamper with the camera, which I haven't done yet, but there were no results with the Robots.  The third time I was successfully able to stop two spheres and move them around the platform quite smoothly.  These spheres were slightly further away from the camera compared to the first run.  I stopped the wooden sphere and the second metal sphere.  I included a screen shot and a copy of my log for the third run.  The spheres in the screenshot are both in a rest position.dware performance or timing concerns can cause this goal to be unnaitanable or trivially easy. The main loop with actually
00299             /// pause execution until this amount of time is reach is main loop iteration, However, the mainloop will always skip waiting if hardware is overburdened.
00300             /// @return This returns a Whole with the current Value
00301             Whole GetTargetFrameTime();
00302 
00303             /// @brief This sets a new Target Time
00304             /// @details This sets a new time for each frame. Each iteration of the game loop will take around this long to run, but rarely exactly this long. Setting this value
00305             /// Higher can results in power savings (battery life), but setting it too High can cause choppiness. Settings this value higher can result in smoother gameplay, but
00306             /// set it too high, and system resources could becom completely taxed and power will be wasted.
00307             /// @param NewTargetTime The new length of time, in milliseconds.
00308             /// @warning Setting vary low or very High values could cause unknown errors, This is on our todo list of issues to fix.
00309             void SetTargetFrameTime(const Whole &NewTargetTime);
00310 
00311             /// @brief This sets a new Target Frame Rate
00312             /// @details This sets a new time for each frame. This divides 1000 by the NewFrameRate, drops and floating point amount and uses that amount in an call to
00313             /// World::SetTargetFrameTime. For example a target frame rate of 40 with cause each frame to take 25 milliseconds, and a Framerate of 70 would take 14 ms
00314             /// @param NewFrameRate The new desired frame rate.
00315             /// @warning Setting vary low or very High values could cause unknown errors, This is on our todo list of issues to fix.
00316             void SetTargetFrameRate(const Whole &NewFrameRate);
00317 
00318             /// @brief Gets the amount of time since the last time Rendering began.
00319             /// @details This returns, in milliseconds the amount of time since the frame started (since the last rendering began)
00320             /// @return This returns a whole number which can be used to aid in the timimg of various algorithms.
00321             Whole GetFrameTime();
00322 
00323             /// @internal
00324             /// @brief Sets the amount of time since the last time Rendering began.
00325             /// @param FrameTime_ This is the amount of time in  milliseconds.
00326             /// @details This sets, in milliseconds the amount of time since the frame started (since the last rendering began). Don't set this carelessely can screw up a lot of
00327             /// stuff, for the most part this should be by the rendering manager during the rendering process.
00328             void SetFrameTime( const Whole &FrameTime_ );

00333             /// @brief This creates the game window and starts the game.
00334             /// @param CallMainLoop should the main loop be called
00335             /// @details Prior to this all of the physics and graphical object containers should have been loaded and prepared for use. There should be
00336             /// minimal delay from the time you call this and the game actually begins.
00337             /// This will automatically call the Main Loop unless passed false.
00338             void GameInit(const bool &CallMainLoop=true );

00340             /// @brief This Function house the main loop
00341             /// @details By default this is called from the function World.GameInit() this is were the bulk of the simulation is ran from, see @ref mainloop1
00342             void MainLoop();

00345             /// @details This is called automatically during the main loop just before rendering.

00348         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00349         // Upper Management
00350         ///////////////////////////////////////
00351             /// @brief This adds a manager, in the correct order, to the list that the world calls on
00352             /// @details Internally the world had a list of managers that is sorted by the ManagerBase::Priority. Everytime a manager is added,
00353             /// the list is searched for the sorted point to insert the manager at.
00354             /// @param ManagerToAdd The pointer to the manager to be added
00355             void AddManager(ManagerBase* ManagerToAdd);
00356 
00357             /// @brief This removes a manager by finding the matching pointer.
00358             /// @details Currently this just iterates through the list looking for the matching pointer, at some future point
00359             /// this could replaced with more sophisticated algorithm, but for now assume this operates in linear time.
00360             /// @param ManagerToRemove A pointer to the manager to be removed
00361             void RemoveManager(ManagerBase* ManagerToRemove);
00362 
00363             /// @brief This removes a manager of a specific type from the list
00364             /// @details This starts at the beginning (should be the lowest priority)of the list and iterates through looking for a matching type, at some future point
00365             /// this could replaced with more sophisticated algorithm, but for now assume this operates in linear time.
00366             /// @param ManagersToRemoveType The ManagerBase::ManagerTypeName of the manager to remove.
00367             /// @param WhichOne If not removing the first/only manager of the given type, which one by count are you erasing.
00368             void RemoveManager(const ManagerBase::ManagerTypeName &ManagersToRemoveType, short unsigned int WhichOne);
00369 
00370             /// @brief This is will find the manager of a given type
00371             /// @details Specifically this will iterate from lowest priority to highest priority, and return a pointer to the first Manager
00372             /// with a matching type found. If you specify WhichOne, it will the Nth+1 in the list matching the type (kind of like array subscript).
00373             /// @param ManagersToRemoveType
00374             /// @param WhichOne If not getting the first/only manager of the given type, get one.
00375             /// @return This returns a pointer to a ManagerBase, or a NULL pointer if no matching manager exists
00376             ManagerBase* GetManager(const ManagerBase::ManagerTypeName &ManagersToRemoveType, short unsigned int WhichOne=0);
00377 
00378             /// @brief Changes a Manager's time of execution.
00379             /// @details Searches through the Manager list and removes any previous entries to the changing manager, and add a new entry in the correct location.
00380             /// @param ManagerToChange A pointer to the manager that needs to be changed
00381             /// @param Priority the new desire priority/execution order of the Manager
00382             void UpdateManagerOrder(ManagerBase* ManagerToChange, short int Priority_);
00383 
00384             /// @brief This forces the list of managers to be resorted.
00385             /// @details This should only need to be called if the Priority attribute of a manager in the list has changed. This sorts the list of managers
00386             void UpdateManagerOrder();
00387 
00388             /// @brief This gets the ActorManager from the manager list.
00389             /// @param WhichOne If you have multiple ActorManagers this will choose which one to return.
00390             /// @return This returns a pointer to a ActorManager, or a NULL pointer if no matching manager exists.
00391             ActorContainerBase* GetActorManager(const short unsigned int &WhichOne=0);

00423             /// @brief This is another way to put data in the log.
00424             /// @details The contents of this will be commited to the log once per frame, just before rendering. Because of that do not
00425             /// use this for data that is likely to be required to debug something the frame something crashes. however, for other kinds of
00426             /// debugging data and creating in game logs and recreations, this can be very useful.
